benchmark_details.name: HalluVerse25
benchmark_details.overview: HalluVerse25 is a fine-grained multilingual LLM hallucination dataset that categorizes fine-grained hallucinations in English, Arabic, and Turkish, providing insight into how well proprietary models perform in detecting LLM-generated hallucinations.

purpose_and_intended_users.goal: To provide a comprehensive dataset that categorizes fine-grained hallucination types across multiple languages and to advance research on LLM hallucination detection.
purpose_and_intended_users.limitations: The dataset is collected based on the availability of biographical information hosted on Wikidata and Wikipedia, which may not represent an accurate distribution of individuals in the world.

data.source: Data was extracted from Wikidata and Wikipedia to create factual sentences which are then modified to inject hallucinations.
data.annotation: Human-annotated by native speakers with a substantial annotation agreement.

methodology.calculation: Models were evaluated based on their ability to correctly classify different types of hallucinations in the dataset.
methodology.interpretation: Higher accuracy indicates better performance in detecting hallucinations of different types.
methodology.baseline_results: GPT-4 demonstrated the highest overall accuracy, especially in identifying entity and relation hallucinations.
methodology.validation: The dataset was validated through a human annotation process with substantial inter-annotator agreement.
